Issues.Title: Deploying a non self-contained app that requires both x64 and x86 runtimes
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: (e.g. 3.0 Preview1, or daily build number, use `dotnet --info`)
3.0 Preview 8

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes/No
No

**Problem description:**
I've ported my application (https://github.com/mscrivo/ootd) to .net core 3 and have run into an interesting problem with the deployment scenario.  According to what I've seen, the only supported deployment mechanisms for .net core 3 wpf/winforms apps are;

1) WSIX packaging
2.) self-contained publish

Neither of these work for my app though, because it has to choose at runtime which platform to it needs to run.  Essentially, the app places instances of the Outlook View Control on your desktop.  So if you are running on Windows 64-bit, but are running 32-bit Outlook, the 32-bit version of my app needs to run in order for it to load the 32-bit COM component.  So what I did in the .net framework world was have a launcher detect which version of Outlook you have installed and run the x64/x86 version of the app appropriately.  Worked beautifully.

Now, with .net core 3.0, it seems I have to choose one or the other, I can't publish a package which contains both x64/x86 runtimes, which means I can't make my app work all scenarios:

windows x86 + office x86
windows x64 + office x86
windows x64 + office x64

The only way for me to make it work is to install both x64/x86 .net core SDKs on the users' system, which is highly impractical.

Are there any plans to support a scenario like this?  Is there some workaround I can use to make this work?

The easiest solution from my point of view, would be to include the WinForms/WPF runtime components in the .net core x64/x86 runtime installers.  Then I can just install both of those on the users' system and it would work. 

Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Deploying a non self-contained app that requires both x64 and x86 runtimes" (#1624)

Issues.Title: Combobox does not fire SelectedIndexChanged event
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0 Preview8
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

**Problem description:**
When using a ComboBox with a SelectedIndexChanged event, the event will not fire if you set the SelectedIndex in the Constructor.

**Actual behavior:**
The SelectedIndexChanged event *only* fires when the "SelectedIndex = 0;" line is run and does not fire when changed by the end-user.

**Expected behavior:**
The SelectedIndexChanged event fires both from the code and from the end-user changing the box in the UI.

**Minimal repro:**
[ComboBoxIssue.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3498883/ComboBoxIssue.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Combobox does not fire SelectedIndexChanged event" (#1620)

Issues.Title: WIP: Fixing 1615: Disabling ToolTip visual styles to make it enough contrasted in HC mode.
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #1615 


## Proposed changes

- Disabling visual styles for ToolTip control in High Contrast mode as Visual Styles prevent setting colors for ToolTip background and text in TTM_SETTIPBKCOLOR and TTM_SETTIPTEXTCOLOR (please see https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/controls/ttm-settipbkcolor and https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/controls/ttm-settiptextcolor
- Visual styles are disabled only for ToolTips and only in HC mode.
- Disabling visual styles for a control is usually performed in OnHandleCreated handler. I've put it just after _window.CreateHandle(cp); call.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- With the fix available customers with visual impairments may observe more contrasted tooltips in WinForms apps.

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/62956301-5f033f00-bdfb-11e9-9fcd-d1373911e855.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/62956323-69bdd400-bdfb-11e9-972a-254f1b880a56.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/62956347-72160f00-bdfb-11e9-98de-a5f39bc83ae3.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/62956375-83f7b200-bdfb-11e9-8ac5-4bc123f6667e.png)

### After

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/62956398-8d811a00-bdfb-11e9-80be-0cde92b80df1.png)


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing.
- Awaiting QA sign-off.
- Color contrast analyzer tools show enough contrast values for new tooltip colors.

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->

Accessibility testing is performed using color contrast analyzer tools.

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

- <!-- use `dotnet --info` -->

 Commit:    795f8aeaa8

Issues.Title: Accessibility: [High Contrast] - Tooltips are not enough contrasted in HC mode
Issues.Body:
.NET Core Version: 3.0.100 Preview8 13316 from master branch
Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes.

**Repro Steps:**
Open control panel and select the respective high contrast theme.
Create WinForms application with some control and add tooltip for this, build and run the app.
Mouse-over the control and wait until ToolTip appears.

**Actual:**
Tooltip is not enough contrasted and its color theme differs from Explorer's Tooltip color theme:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/62955258-675a7a80-bdf9-11e9-9fde-c3d6798a90c5.png)

**Expected:**
Tooltip background and foreground colors should have maximum contrast in HC mode:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/62955398-ac7eac80-bdf9-11e9-8e12-5ee4d8852d93.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Accessibility: [High Contrast] - Tooltips are not enough contrasted in HC mode" (#1615)

Issues.Title: ListView slow and max width
Issues.Body:
ListView becomes slow when it contains many columns, even if only a few of them are displayed. Here is a sample code that illustrates the issue. When you try to scroll it, it takes a long time to repaint. Virtual mode does not help. I am not really sure why it takes so long to paint 120 cells.

```vbnet
Private ListView1 As New ListView With {.Size = New Size(300, 400)}

Private Sub Form1_Load(sender As Object, e As EventArgs) Handles Me.Load
    Const columns = 600
    Controls.Add(ListView1)

    With ListView1
        .BeginUpdate()
        .View = View.Details
        .HeaderStyle = ColumnHeaderStyle.Nonclickable

        For c = 1 To columns
            .Columns.Add(c.ToString, 50, HorizontalAlignment.Center)
        Next

        For r = 1 To 20
            Dim l As New ListViewItem(r & "1")
            For c = 2 To columns
                l.SubItems.Add(r & c)
            Next
            .Items.Add(l)
        Next
        .EndUpdate()
    End With
End Sub
```
Another issue I found is that it looks like there is a limitation of how large the width of all columns can be, i. e. in my sample code you can change the column count to 700 and observe how the last columns will not be visible.  The last ones that will be visible will not allow you to change their width.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ListView slow and max width" (#1606)

Issues.Title: Fix tooltip crash and harden
Issues.Body:
The tooltip class will cause Windows to AV when attempting to get the tooltip bubble size when there isn't an actively showing tooltip. (Really Windows should be checking before derefing their internal pointer, but this has been there forever.) Fixing this by making sure to check that one is active when sending the query message.

The existing TooInfo usage was not safe and could crash with bad timing with a GC. I've hardened usage of the TTTOOLINFO struct and made it blittable, which should make things both safe and more performant as we're not instantiating a class anymore.

Fixes #1602.

## Proposed changes

- Refactor TTOOLINFO to guard against AVs
- Fix the explicit AV in #1602

## Customer Impact

- Won't easily AV
- Better performance

## Regression? 

- Yes - Introduced in 4.8

## Risk

- Reasonably low- it is much easier to reason about the code with this change

## Test methodology

- Manual testing with Tooltip
- Debugging into Windows to validate behavior

Issues.Title: update SDK used to build winforms to latest release channel SDK
Issues.Body:
We like to do this now and again so that we are:
1. building on latest bits aside from the RuntimeFrameworkVersion
1. demonstrating an up-to-date .NET sdk version global.json (are good examples to others looking to build on our stack)
1. find problems as a result of this earlier

This should be the last rev until we update to 3.1 RTM

Issues.Title: Add static using for Interop
Issues.Body:
WinForms has a ton of interop- using `Interop.Gdi.` doesn't provide much value over `Gdi.` and just increases clutter. Switching all of the current files to add `using static Interop;` to improve readability.

We've also done this in the designer.

## Proposed changes

- Switch all files to use `using static Interop;`

## Customer Impact

- None, makes code easier to read/maintain.

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Very low- just replace all and manual using insert.

## Test methodology

- Built, ran tests.


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/1608)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add static using for Interop" (#1608)

Issues.Title: Wilcard include interop files for System.Windows.Forms
Issues.Body:
So far System.Windows.Forms is the superset of Interop usage. There was one existing wildcard that wasn't properly defined, including all of interop as one wildcard to make continued work here easier (less conflicts, easier to add files).

If we need to exclude individual files we can add those explicitly. If needed we can break this out into individual subdirectories as well.

The other projects include only a subset of the interop definitions, so keeping those explicit.

## Customer Impact

None

## Regression? 

No

## Risk

Very low

## Test methodology

- Built, ran tests.

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Wilcard include interop files for System.Windows.Forms" (#1601)

Issues.Title: Scrollable MessageBox
Issues.Body:
The problem's pretty much obvoius: sometimes standard messageboxes are just too short for the contents:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24297712/62801559-b13c1b80-baee-11e9-9891-7862c678944a.png)

There was already good and working solution of this problem. More info:
https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/601900/FlexibleMessageBox-A-Flexible-Replacement-for-the

The mentioned FlexibleMessageBox class works well on .NET Core 3 WinForms application, but probably that behaviour of MessageBox should be default?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Scrollable MessageBox" (#1600)

Issues.Title: Convert the rest of interop for Cursor
Issues.Body:
## Proposed changes

- Make all of Cursor Interop clean.
- Update other classes with related imports to use static Interop (which we're doing in the designer)
- Clean style in DeviceContext and WindowsGraphics
- Introduce internal IHandle to make GC.KeepAlive wraps easier

## Customer Impact

- Better perf for IPicture related code paths
- More robust for said code paths

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Low

## Test methodology

- Ensured areas had test coverage and ran tests


Note that I wanted to get this up to demonstrate some patterns, notably:

1. Using `IHandle` to start providing keepalive overloads
2. Using static for `Interop` (as we're doing in the designer repo now)
3. Union handling (see `PICTDESC`)
4. Generic pattern for `GetObject`
5. Ref disposable pattern on native structs (see `ICONINFO`)

Whether or not we take it for 3.0 I wanted these examples visible.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/1604)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Convert the rest of interop for Cursor" (#1604)

Issues.Title: Fix screen related tests
Issues.Body:
Recently added tests are not multimonitor friendly. Screens frequently have negative coordinates. The common case is with the primary screen to the right of the secondary screen. The primary screen origin is 0,0. Anything to the left or above will have negative coordinates (including the virtual screen).

## Customer Impact

None- this is a test break.

## Regression? 

No

## Risk

None, test only change.

## Test methodology

- Ran tests on multimonitor system

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Fix screen related tests" (#1603)

Issues.Title: AccessViolationException with MenuStrip and VisualStyleState.NoneEnabled
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: .NET Core Version: 3.0.0-preview7-27912-14 * Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No **Problem description:** When you disable visual stiles: ```c# Application.VisualStyleState = System.Windows.Forms.VisualStyles.VisualStyleState.NoneEnabled; // Application.EnableVisualStyles(); ``` The winForms mdi app with MenuStrip ans submenus are crushed with AccessViolationException, after you open sub menu and live it (move cursor out of the menu - see gif below). Windows 7 pro x64. **Actual behavior:**
Exception, Event logs, Gif of the error ![nc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17767561/62825179-43582880-bbb0-11e9-9f4a-52489d518be8.gif) `AccessViolationException: Attempted to read or write protected memory. This is often an indication that other memory is corrupt.` ``` Application: WinFormsCoreTest.exe CoreCLR Version: 4.700.19.32702 .NET Core Version: 3.0.0-preview7-27912-14 Description: The process was terminated due to an internal error in the .NET Runtime at IP 000007FEC76FA8D4 (000007FEC7540000) with exit code c0000005. ``` ``` Faulting application name: WinFormsCoreTest.exe, version: 1.0.0.0, time stamp: 0x5d29536d Faulting module name: coreclr.dll, version: 4.700.19.32702, time stamp: 0x5d155e43 Exception code: 0xc0000005 Fault offset: 0x00000000001ba8d4 Faulting process id: 0x248c Faulting application start time: 0x01d54f9f444a10b0 Faulting application path: D:\save\projects\WinFormsCoreTest\bin\Debug\netcoreapp3.0\WinFormsCoreTest.exe Faulting module path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App\3.0.0-preview7-27912-14\coreclr.dll Report Id: b32877c1-bb92-11e9-8c38-40b0760b80f2 ```
**Expected behavior:** No AccessViolationException. **Minimal repro:** [WinFormsCoreTest.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3489165/WinFormsCoreTest.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "AccessViolationException with MenuStrip and VisualStyleState.NoneEnabled" (#1602)

Issues.Title: MenuBar checkbox color is different between .NET Core 3 and .NET Framework
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0 Preview 7
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

**Problem description:**
MenuBar's MenuItem has a different color when it is checked (with no mouse hovering) between .NET Framework and .NET Core 3. The color for .NET Core 3 appears to be a bug, as I wouldn't have expected it to have the solid blue background, nor a different checkmark, as shown below.

**Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
.NET Core 3:
![NetCoreApp3 0-Issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/808932/62789153-57a80280-ba96-11e9-9a1f-7ca244353854.PNG)

**Expected behavior:**
.NET Framework
![Net471-NoIssue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/808932/62789167-61316a80-ba96-11e9-8a63-d187a3efe792.PNG)


**Minimal repro:**
[Repo.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3486911/Repo.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MenuBar checkbox color is different between .NET Core 3 and .NET Framework" (#1597)
